body.p: Which distribution is a plausible representation of 100 samples, with each sample containing 50 randomly selected students?

response.feedback: Incorrect. It is true that this distribution could have a mean of μ = 2,600, but the standard deviation looks like it is smaller than the predicted value of 70 (σ/√(n) = 500/√(50) ≅ 70). Using the Standard Deviation Rule,approximately 68% of the values should be between 2,530 and 2,670 (within one standard deviation of the mean.) In Graph A this range covers more than 68% of the values, as shown.

Correct. The sampling distribution will have a mean of 2,600 and a standard deviation of 70. Using the Standard Deviation Rule, approximately 68% of the values should be between 2,530 and 2,670 (within 1 standard deviation of the mean.). Graph B looks like it could fit this description.

Incorrect. It is true that this distribution could have a mean at μ = 2,600, but the standard deviation looks like it is much larger than the predicted value of 70: σ/√(n) = 500/√(50) ≅ 70. Using the Standard Deviation Rule, approximately 68% of the values should be between 2,530 and 2,670 (within 1 standard deviation of the mean.) In Graph C this range covers a very small percentage of the values, as shown.
Incorrect. The sampling distribution should have a mean at μ = 2,600.
